Graphical abstract Anionic resin supported peroxo phosphotungstic acid catalysts with different contents of peroxo phosphotungstic acid are prepared through a simple anion-exchange from spherical chloride-form resin pre-treated with organic amine. Thus-prepared materials possess typical Keggin structures, irregular morphologies, high metal content, as revealed by XRD, SEM, TEM, EDX, and IR. UV-vis, Raman and XPS spectra prove the formation of peroxo phosphotungstic acid in high dispersion on the resin. Among these solid catalysts, chloromethylated polystyrene resin-supported peroxo phosphotungstic acid (PSC-3) exhibits the best activity for the titled reaction to obtain 91.8mol% conversion of dicyclopentadiene and 90.0% selectivity of mono-epoxide. PSC-3 catalyst behaves as a truly heterogeneous catalyst that can be reused nine times without any loss of activity. Some factors play important roles in controlling the mono-epoxidation. Keywords Chloride-form resin Peroxo phosphotungstic acid Dicyclopentadiene Mono-epoxidation H2O2 1 Introduction Olefin epoxides are well known as one of the most valuable processes that can be a major industrial reaction for the production of a broad variety of organic intermediates [1–5]. Moreover, some of these epoxides play an important role owing to their lively chemical properties and are therefore very valuable as precursors for the development of fine chemicals [6–8]. There has been a great deal of interest in epoxidation of olefins catalyzed by polyoxometalates (POMs) that constitute a versatile class of inorganic, anionic clusters that have applications involving medicine, catalysis, materials science, geochemistry, nuclear waste processing, and photochemical or electrochemical response [9–17]. In the 1980s, phosphatotungstate was applied to catalyze the epoxidation of different alkenes with hydrogen peroxide by the groups of Venturello [18,19] and Ishii [20], which showed high activity and selectivity for the epoxidation of olefins. But there was several disadvantages as homogeneous catalysts, for example, the recovery of the catalyst from the reaction mixture is often troublesome, the possible formation of a stable emulsion at the end of the reaction complicates the separation of the two phases and the use of toxic and carcinogenic chlorocarbons (chloroform and 1,2-dichloroe −thane) as solvents cannot be avoided [21,22]. The solution to circumvent these drawbacks is to immobilize the catalyst by means of many methodologies (adsorption, covalent linkage, ion exchange, physical entrapment, etc.) [9,23]. In the past few decades, some materials, such as some silica materials [24], Amberlite IRA-900 ion exchange resin [25,26], layered double hydroxides (LDH) [27] and ionic liquid-modified polystyrene resin [9], were reported as carrier for the active species. These heterogeneous supported catalysis perform great abilities with the aqueous hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant, which is an insoluble solid and can dissolve into the reaction solution when it reacts with hydrogen peroxide, and the catalyst becomes insoluble solid and precipitate again after the epoxidation reaction is over [28–35]. Recently, the efficient heterogeneous oxidation catalysts by the immobilization of phosphorus-containing tetranuclear peroxotungstate ([PO4 −{WO(O2)2}4]3−, denoted by PW4) onto zinc modified SnO2 supports [PW4 −Zn(x)/SnO2, in which x denotes the zinc content (wt%)] were synthesized by Susu mu Nojima et al. The PW4 −Zn(x)/SnO2 catalysts, in particular PW4 −Zn(0.8)/SnO2, could act as efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the H2O2-based oxidation of various types of organic substrates [23]. Notably, the catalytic performance of PW4 −Zn(0.8)/SnO2 was much superior to those of the corresponding homogeneous analogue THA3PW4 (THA=tetra-n-hexylammonium) as well as the previously reported tungstate-based heterogeneous catalysts such as W−Zn/SnO2 [23,36,37]. In the present work, we have successfully prepared the chloromethylated polystyrene resin-supported peroxo phosphotungstic acid (PSC) heterogeneous catalysts by a simple anion-exchange of H3PW4O24 onto a commercially available chloromethylated polystyrene resin (PS) quaternized by a long-chain organic amine (C12H25N(CH3)2). The PSC catalysts show high catalytic performance for the selective mono-epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene to the corresponding mono-epoxide. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Chloromethylated polystyrene resin (PS) were commercial products purchased from Nankai Chemical Plant. Note that PS resin are styrene-divinylbenzene type ones containing exchangeable chloride anions, for which the compositions and anion-exchange capacities of these anion resins are shown in Scheme 1 and Table 1 . Dicyclopentadiene (>99%), bicyclicalkenyl ester (>98%), cyclooctadiene (>99%), 4-vinyl-1-cyclohexene (>99%), cyclododecatriene (>99%), diallyl ether (>99%), 1,5-hexadiene (>99%), acetonitrile (>99%, CH3CN), 1,4-dioxane (>99%), dimethyl formamide (>99%, DMF), toluene (>99%), acetone (>99%), dichloroethane (>99%), dimethyl carbonate (>99%), tungstic acid (H3WO4), hydrogen peroxide (30%, H2O2), phosphoric acid (85%, H3PO4), N,N'-dimethyl dodecylamine (DMDA, >99%), aqueous tert-butyl hydroperoxide (65%, TBHP), sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) and cumyl hydroperoxide (>70%, CHP) were purchased and used as received. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts PS resins that had been ground into fine powders required one pretreatment for the removal of impurities prior to use [34]. In a 100-ml 3-necked flask, the mixture of 2.5g anion resin and 50ml ethanol was refluxed at 80°C for 24h. Then, the solid was recovered by filtration and washed thoroughly with deionized water. Note that above-said two steps were repeated once. The recovered resin was washed by acetone, and then dried at 80°C for 2h. A certain amount of N,N'-dimethyl dodecylamine and PS (molar ratio is 1.2:1 (the chlorine content of the resin)) were separately added into a hot ethanol solution, and stirred at 78°C for 10h to ensure the formation of quaternary cations. In order to remove the excess organic amine, the recovered solids that had been washed several times with hot ethanol, again subjected to the Soxhlet extraction in ethanol under refluxing 48h. In the meantime, 7.80mmol tungstic acid, 1.95mmol phosphoric acid, and 10ml 30% H2O2, and 40ml water were added into a 100-ml 3-necked flask to obtain a mixture solution, which was stirred at 60°C overnight. Subsequently, the resin was added into a solution of preformed peroxo phosphoric acid and aged at 60°C for 1h under shaking, which was then heated to 80°C for the anion-exchange treatment for 5h. Finally, the powder resin catalyst was recovered by filtration, washed with deionized water until neutral, and then washed by acetone, followed by drying at 60°C for 2h. Besides, chloromethylated polystyrene resin-supported peroxo phosphotungstic acid (PSC) catalysts with different P contents (0, 0.57, 0.66, 0.84, 0.99 and 1.18wt%) were prepared through above-said anion-exchange treatment of resin PS with aqueous solutions of different P concentrations, and named as chloromethylated polystyrene resin-supported peroxo tungstate (PS-T), PSC-1, PSC-2, PSC-3 and PSC-4 (Scheme 1). 2.3 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were recorded on a Rigaku D/MAX-IIIC diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.54184Å) operating at 30kV and 25mA. The average crystal sizes were estimated from SEM images, which were observed using a JEOL JSM 6500F scanning electron microscope (SEM) operating at an accelerating voltage of 25kV and a tube current of 100μA under vacuum at 10−6 mbar, where the setup was coupled to an Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS) for micro-analysis. TEM images were obtained using FEI Tecnai G20 at accelerating voltage of 200kV. UV–vis spectra of samples were determined on a Shimadzu UV-2550 spectrometer. The Kubelka–Munk function was used to convert reflectance measurements into equivalent absorption spectra using the reflectance of BaSO4 as a reference, and to obtain absorption edge energies directly from the curves. Laser Raman spectra (LRS) spectra were measured on a Renishaw InVia Confocal Raman microscope, in which A50×/N.A.0.75 objective and a 532-nm DPSS laser excitation source (∼120mW) were used. The spectra within a Raman shift window were recorded using a mounted CCD camera and integrated over one period of 10s at room temperature. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted using a thermo-conductive detector (TCD) mounted on a TP-5076 TPD/TPR analyzer. Fifty milligrams of catalyst was first pretreated at 150°C for 30min in a N2 flow of 40ml/min and then cooled down to room temperature. After that, NH3 adsorption was conducted at room temperature for 30min. Finally, NH3-TPD was carried out in an N2 flow (40ml/min) from room temperature to 400°C at a rate of 10°C/min. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the catalysts was performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851e under N2 flowing of 60ml/min at heating rate of 20°C/min up to 800°C. 2.4 Mono-epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene The catalytic epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene (Scheme 2 ) was carried out in a 25-mL two-necked round-bottom glass flask equipped with a cryogenic-liquid condenser under atmospheric pressure. Typically, 10.0mmol of dicyclopentadiene, 10.0mmol of H2O2, 4.0g of acetonitrile and 300mg of the catalyst were added into the reactor. Note that H2O2 was added by four times and each time lasted ten minutes. The mixture was vigorously stirred by a magnetic stirrer and heated to desired temperature in a water bath. After the completion of the reaction, the solid powder catalyst was recovered by filtration and washed thoroughly with acetone and ethanol, and dried at 60°C overnight for the next use. The liquid filtrate was analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with a capillary column (Rtx@5, 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm) and an FID detector, in which chlorobenzene was used as an internal standard to quantify all the components. As illustrated in Scheme 1, the epoxidized products were mainly consisted of mono-epoxide, di-epoxide, di-enol and others (a little amount of byproducts), 1H and 13C NMR spectra of mono-epoxides were shown in Fig. S1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterstics of catalysts The EDX (energy-dispersive X-ray) analysis confirms a uniform distribution of active components in this composite material. As can be seen from Table 1, with increasing the loading concentration of peroxo phosphotungstic acid, the contents of P and W in the catalyst are increased stepwise. As shown in Table 1, the contents of P and W are the highest in the PSC-4 catalyst. As revealed by the IR spectra of HPW (phosphotungstic acid) in the literature [38–40], the absorption peaks of 1080, 983 and 891cm−1 are attributed to PO, WO, WOW vibrations. In comparison with pure HPW, the PSC catalysts have the three absorption peaks of PO (1085cm−1), WO (986cm−1), WOW (901cm−1) vibrations are little red-shifed (Fig. 1 ), probably due to resin-bound peroxy phosphotungstic acid anion with Keggin structure present on the PS. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of pure PS and PSC samples. As we known, the pure HPW catalyst shows the characteristic Keggin structure of heteropoly acids. [41] No any peak is observed from the XRD patterns of PSC-1–PSC-4 samples. This observation supports the notion that peroxy phosphotungstic acid is homogeneously dispersed in porous structures. This finding demonstrates that the peroxy phosphotungstic acid species are finely and molecularly dispersed on the surface of PS via chemical interaction. As attempted in this work, it is believed that heteropolyanions are strongly immobilized on resins PS as charge compensating components. The UV–vis spectra of various samples are shown in Fig. S2, where shows the absorption bands at 233 and 263nm of peroxo phosphotungstic acid. As for the PS resin itself, several broad and strong absorptions appear in the range from 220 to 266nm and 360nm. PSC samples exhibit broad and strong absorptions in the range from 215 to 260nm, different from PS resin. The blue shifts are observed, possibly due to the effect of peroxo phosphotungstic acid anions introduced into the framework of PS resin on coordinative environments. The Raman spectra of PS and PSC catalysts are shown in Fig. S3. The spectrum of HPW is in accordance with that reported in the literature, [42,43] while the bulk peroxo phosphotungstic acid exhibits Raman bands at 897, 980, 989 and 1005cm−1 for v as(WOW), ν as(W–Ot), ν as(W–Ot) and ν as(W=Ot), respectively, which again do not correlate with those for the PSC catalysts. This also demonstrates that the peroxo phosphotungstic acid species are finely and highly dispersed on the surface of PS. The SEM images of catalysts are shown in Fig. S4. Clearly, the morphologies of catalysts by anion-exchange treatment are still similar to that of parent chloromethylated polystyrene (PS) resin. This means that the framework structure of the resin PS is not destroyed and the active sites have been highly dispersed on its surface. The TEM micrographs in Fig. 3 demonstrate uniform lamellar structure of PS and PSC-3 catalysts. The TEM images of PSC-3 (Fig. 3b), revealing the characteristic structural feature of the PS (Fig. 3a) materials. This result clearly indicates that the samples keep the unique pore structure of the parent support very well. The XPS measurements were performed to identify elemental composition of multilayer films deposited on the PSC catalysts. The survey spectrum of the film shows the presence of C1s (BE=286.08eV), N1s (BE=404.08eV),W4f (BE=39.08eV) and O1s (BE=533.08eV) core levels with no evidence of impurities (shown in Fig. 4 a). The 404.08eV peak is attributed to the carbon bound to N atom of PSC. Fig. 4b shows the W4f core-level spectrum with two peaks centered at binding energies of 35.58, and 37.78eV. The W4f7/2 (35.58eV) is ascribed to the HPW. Fig. 4c shows the O1s spectrum, where the 530.78eV BE peak is ascribed to the W–O bonding present in HPW. Fig. 4d shows the spectrum of the C1s core level. The 284.68eV peak can be assigned to the alkyl carbon of PSC. These XPS results again confirm the existence of the PS, HPW, and N in the multilayer film in conjunction with the results of FTIR and UV-vis spectra. Two exothermic weight losses are observed for the PS sample at ∼120 and 230°C, which are attributed to the loss of water and the decomposition of the PS hydrocarbon tail (Fig. 5 ). The total weight loss of 70wt% by 500°C indicates the thermal stability of PS. For the PS-T and PSC hybrid, the major weight loss occurs at 230 and 340°C, with a total weight loss of 80wt% by 450°C, consistent with the hydrocarbon content determined by elemental analysis. The thermal stability of PSC suggests a direct interaction between the PS and phosphotungstic acid anions, possibly via the coordination of organic amine head group with the HPW species. The acidity on PSC catalysts has been evaluated by NH3-TPD analysis, as shown in Fig. 6 . It is known that PS material exhibits one main desorption peak below 120°C, usually assigned to the physisorption of ammonia on very weak acid sites [44,45]. However, the acidity on PSC-1 is certainly related to the phosphotungstic acid species loaded on PS. For the PSC-1 catalyst, the desorption peak emerges at 172°C, higher than that of PS (110°C), implying the enhanced acidity of the catalyst caused by the HPW loading. Distinctly, the TPD profile of PSC-3 shows a major desorption peak at 174°C and a slope between 75 and 255°C, indicating the co-existence of weak and strong acid sites. The peak at 90.8°C is due to the interaction of NH3 with weak acid sites contributed by non-substituted chlorine groups in high dispersion, while the signal between 115 and 255°C corresponds to medium and strong acid sites (phosphotungstic acid). 3.2 Catalytic mono-epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene 3.2.1 The epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene over various PSC catalysts Various anion-exchanged catalysts have been applied to catalyze the mono-epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene with H2O2, as demonstrated in Table 2 . Under identical experimental conditions, various catalysts show different catalytic properties. When only PS is added (no peroxo phosphotungstic acid supported on PS), there is no epoxidation reaction. The use of PS-T as the catalyst converts 62.5 mol% dicyclopentadiene, with 86.5% selectivity of mono-epoxide. From Table 3 , one can see that PSC-3 achieves 91.8 mol% conversion of dicyclopentadiene and 71.1% selectivity of mono-epoxide under the same reaction conditions. The other products include di-epoxide and diol. The catalytic activity can be arranged in the order of PSC–3>PSC–4>PSC–2>PSC–1>PS-T, slightly different from the descending order of the mono-epoxide selectivity: PSC–2>PSC–3=PSC–1>PS-T>PSC-4. Based on the above results, powdered PSC-3 is considered to be an effective catalyst with high activity. A comparison of our results with the earlier data reported for the epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene is summarized in Table 3, which further shows the excellent activity of our epoxidation system using PSC-3 as the catalyst. According to the methods reported in the literature, [46–48] the conversion gradually decreases in the order of WO3∙H2O (100%)>Aliquat 366 (98.0%)>PSC-3 (91.8%)>LDH-[Fe(Cl)salen] (82.0%), slightly different from the descending order of the mono-epoxide selectivity: LDH-[Fe(Cl)salen] (100%)>PSC-3 (90.0%)>Aliquat 366 (55.0%)>WO3∙H2O (50.0%). 3.2.2 Effect of various reaction conditions Further investigations have shown the importance of a suitable solvent for the titled epoxidation (Table 4 ). As we have known, the solvent plays a key role in determining the reaction rate or the distribution of products. The tested solvents include CH3CN, dioxane, DMF, toluene, acetone, dichloroethane and dimethyl carbonate. The conversion of dicyclopentadiene decreases in the sequence of CH3CN (91.8 mol%)>DMF (78.3mol%)>dimethyl carbonate (77.7mol%)>dichloroethane (71.7 mol%)>acetone (60.7mol%)>dioxane (60.1 mol%)>toluene (22.7mol%). As can be seen from Table 3, it seems that CH3CN is preferred for the selective epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene to mono-epoxide. The effect of the catalyst amount on the conversion and selectivity is illustrated in Fig. 7 . When the amount of the catalyst PSC-3 is increased from 50 to 300mg, the conversion of dicyclopentadiene is rapidly increased from 30.5 to 91.8 mol%, while the selectivity of mono-epoxide is slightly decreased from 96.7 to 90.0%. With a further increase of the catalyst amount from 300 to 400mg, the conversion of dicyclopentadiene is continuously increased from 91.8 to 93.0 mol%, but the selectivity of mono-epoxide undergoes a decrease from 90.0 to 86.3%. This shows that the addition of excess catalyst is unbeneficial to the selective epoxidation of mono-epoxide, but conducive to the increase of di-epoxide. Various oxidants including H2O2, TBHP, CHP, NaClO and air are tested to epoxidize dicyclopentadiene over PSC-3 at 50°C. When no any oxidant is added, no epoxidation occurs at 50°C. As compared with H2O2, TBHP, CHP, NaClO and air are less efficient for the epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene under the present experimental conditions (Table 5 ). When 65% TBHP is used as the oxidant, the conversion of dicyclopentadiene is 27.0 mol% with 68.3% selectivity of mono-epoxide. Using 70% CHP as the oxidant, 54.6 mol% conversion of dicyclopentadiene is obtained with 94.9% selectivity of mono-epoxide. NaClO achieves 1.8 mol% conversion and about 15.6% selectivity of mono-epoxide. When air is used as the oxidant, no epoxidation occurs at 50°C. The effect of reaction temperature is illustrated in Fig. 8 . Obviously, the reaction temperature has a distinct influence on the catalytic epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene. When the reaction temperature is increased from 20 to 50°C, the conversion of dicyclopentadiene is largely increased from 50.5 to 91.8 mol%. Along with a further increase of reaction temperature from 50 to 60°C, the conversion of dicyclopentadiene is slightly decreased from 91.8 to 87.8 mol%, possibly attributed to the decomposition of H2O2 at higher reaction temperatures. Low reaction temperature results in low conversion. The selectivity of mono-epoxide is relatively stable in the range of 94.2-92.8% at the temperature from 20 to 40°C, but drops to 90.0% at 50°C and 88.2% at 60°C. The decrease in the selectivity of mono-epoxide at high temperatures is probably related with the formation of di-epoxide as the side product. Fig. S5 shows the effect of reaction time on the epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene with H2O2 over PSC-3. Within the reaction time of 1h, the conversion of dicyclopentadiene is about 49.1 mol%, then sharply increased to 71.6 mol% in 2h, to 83.0 mol% in 4h and to 91.8 mol% in 6h with prolonging the reaction time. Comparatively, the selectivity of mono-epoxide is decreased from 95.3 to 85.2%, probably due to the increase of side product di-epoxide. The yield of mono-epoxide reaches the maximum of 82.6 mol% in 4h, which is the optimal time. Furthermore, control experiments are carried out according to the method described in the literature [49]. As shown in Fig. S5, after the epoxidation reaction is initially conducted for 1h, the conversion of dicyclopentadiene reaches 49.1 mol%. Then, the solid catalyst is filtered off and the reaction is continued for another 5h. The final conversion analyzed by GC merely shows a small increment of 3.4 mol% on PSC-3, attributable to the non-catalytic oxidation of dicyclopentadiene by H2O2, which further confirms the characteristics of heterogeneous catalysis. 3.3 Recycling studies The recycling uses of the catalyst PSC-3 for the epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene to mono-epoxide have been carried out to monitor its recyclable stability. As listed in Fig. 9 , the reuses eight times of PSC-3 do not appreciably decrease the conversion of dicyclopentadiene and the selectivity of mono-epoxide. This could be ascribed to the strong interaction of peroxy phosphotungstic acid with the resin support, further inhibiting the leaching of the active ingredient during the reaction. The conversion of dicyclopentadiene is always kept at 91.3–91.8 mol%, while the selectivity of mono-epoxide has kept an inconspicuous fluctuation of around 89.9–90.2%. For the first recycle, ICP analyses of the reaction mixture and the used catalyst did not detect the leaching of peroxy phosphotungstic acid from PSC-3. For the latter seven recycles, still no leaching of peroxy phosphotungstic acid was detected. This study further reveals the recyclable stability of the active catalyst PSC-3 for the titled reaction. 3.4 Catalytic mono-epoxidation of various dienes Aside from the catalytic mono-epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene with H2O2 as stated above, that of other six olefins over PSC-3 is as well described in Table 6 . About 72.7 mol% of 4-vinyl-1-cyclohexene is converted to achieve 73.3% selectivity of mono-epoxide. However, the reactivity of bicyclicalkenyl ester, cyclooctadiene, cyclododecatriene, 1,5-hexadiene or diallyl ether is obviously lower than those of dicyclopentadiene and 4-vinyl-1-cyclohexene, possibly due to steric hindrances or low π-electron density of these alkene molecules decreasing the possibility of electrophilic cycloaddition in the epoxidation. [50] Comparatively, the reactivity of seven olefins decreases in a sequence of dicyclopentadiene (91.8 mol%)>4-vinyl-1-cyclohexene (72.7mol%)>cyclododecatriene (58.9 mol%)>cyclooctadiene (56.2 mol%)>diallyl ether (54.5mol%)>bicyclicalkenyl ester (52.8 mol%)>1,5-hexadiene (42.6 mol%), totally different from the descending order of the mono-epoxide selectivity of 4-vinyl-1-cyclohexene (90.3%)> dicyclopentadiene (90.0%)>cyclooctadiene (85.3%)>cyclododecatriene (82.6%)>bicyclicalkenyl ester (73.3%)>1,5-hexadiene (72.8%)>diallyl ether (58.9%). 4 Conclusions Active peroxo phosphotungstic acid anion-exchanged resin solid catalyst (PSC) has been successfully prepared through a simple anion-exchange procedure, and widely characterized by various analyses. The high catalytic activity of PSC toward high conversion of dicyclopentadiene and high selectivity of mono-epoxide is ascribed to the contribution of peroxo phosphotungstic acid in high dispersion. Thus-synthesized catalyst PSC-3 shows an excellent activity with 91.8 mol% conversion of dicyclopentadiene and 90.0% selectivity of mono-epoxide at the molar ratio of 1 (alkene): 1 (H2O2) under normal pressure. And, this catalyst is heterogeneously recyclable. Some factors like the type of anionic resins, solvents, catalyst amount, oxidants, temperature and time exert notable impacts on the epoxidation reaction. Also, this catalyst shows good catalytic activity for the epoxidation of 4-vinyl-1-cyclohexene, but relatively poor ones for other dienes or triene. coredata.dc:description: Anionic resin supported peroxo phosphotungstic acid catalysts with different contents of peroxo phosphotungstic acid are prepared through a simple anion-exchange from spherical chloride-form resin pre-treated with organic amine. Thus-prepared materials possess typical Keggin structures, irregular morphologies, high metal content, as revealed by XRD, SEM, TEM, EDX, and IR. UV-vis, Raman and XPS spectra prove the formation of peroxo phosphotungstic acid in high dispersion on the resin. Among these solid catalysts, chloromethylated polystyrene resin-supported peroxo phosphotungstic acid (PSC-3) exhibits the best activity for the titled reaction to obtain 91.8mol% conversion of dicyclopentadiene and 90.0% selectivity of mono-epoxide. PSC-3 catalyst behaves as a truly heterogeneous catalyst that can be reused nine times without any loss of activity. Some factors play important roles in controlling the mono-epoxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective mono-epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene with aqueous H2O2 over heterogeneous peroxo-phosphotungstic catalysts
